HIS MAJESTY'S SECOND LIEUTENANTS I This for the Cheerio Optimists, His Majesty's Second-Lieutenants; With the milk on their mouths and the time on their wrists, His Majesty's Second-Lieutenants: âAbout as wise as the unlick'd cubâ Was written in heaven of the average Sub, But they all belonged to the Suicide Club, His Majesty's Second-Lieutenants. II The Colonel's grief and the Sergeant's curse, His Majesty's Second-Lieutenants; The Regiments took 'em for better or worse, His Majesty's Second-Lieutenants; A sort of medicine for the soulâ Yet pledge 'em deep in the loving-bowl, For they spread the honour thick on the roll, His Majesty's Second-Lieutenants. III Lords of the enduring, triumphing line, His Majesty's Second-Lieutenants; Nearest, forever, to the Rhine, His Majesty's Second-Lieutenants; Children who fathered veteran hosts In flame-rack'd fields and blood-soak'd posts, And so gave up their proud young ghostsâ His Majesty's Second-Lieutenants! INTERCESSION Made in Thine image, quickened of Thy breath, Who givest us life and givest us, also, death; By Spear and Sponge and Thorn and Bitter Tree, O, Judge and Comforter, we call on Thee. Sick broods the sun with agony of Thy wars, Aghast Thy moon, weary Thine ageing stars. Behold the garden which Thou saw'st âwas goodâ Is but a charnel and a place of blood! Broken the golden bowl and all unloosed The silver girdle. Friendly doors we used Are shut and darkened. On the aching street The mourners go, and only mourners meet. There is no man hath joy of mart or grove, There is no woman hath not lost a love, There is no stripling bears not in his eyes The anguish of the fore-doomed sacrifice. Our sins were scarlet, stubborn was our pride, And yet . . . the Smitten Cheek, the Wounded Side! Avails it not that from yon vineyards rise The crosses of ten thousand Calvaries? These were Thy faithful servants, Lord, no less, Who lay down humbly in their loveliness, Thine is the Kingdom that they cherished thus: If Thou rememberest them, remember us. So that Thy will be done upon this earth Welcome be woe and travail and tears and dearth, Grant us the strength of conquerors. We stand Submissive in the hollow of Thy hand. THE SILENCE Amid the turmoil And the rush, A golden pause, A silver hush! A quietness Which uttereth Speech down the vasty Lines of death; Which saith to them Who lie so still By foreign flood And alien hill: âDear are your names And sweet to hear, Because this land To you was dear: âThis fair, fair landâ Unravished ground, Because your love Folded it round! âAnd these our children Blest and freeâ Becaues of your Gethsemane!â Oh Graciousness That kept the trust, Oh lovers In the dreaming dust, Thus shall our love For you be proved: We keep and love What you so loved. âMUDDY BOOTSâ Muddy Boots! Muddy Boots! Charing Cross for Muddy Boots; Six days' leave they've given himâ He went out most gay and trim,â Comes back threadbare, soiled and grim, A picture for the clean recruits, But very glorious,âMuddy Boots! Muddy Boots! Muddy Boots! London town for Muddy Boots, After week on week on week Of trench and stench and rain and reek And ghastly games at âHide-and-seekâ And âAll-fall-down!â among the brutes; (Seen 'em close, has Muddy Boots!) Muddy Boots! Muddy Boots! âFeeling strangeâ is Muddy Boots, And nervous of the folks he meets; For babes salute him in the streets, And ladies offer him their seats On crowded tubes and L.G. routes, Blushes up, does Muddy Boots! Muddy Boots; Muddy Boots! Dream's come true for Muddy Boots, You can read it in his eyes, HOME, the soldier's paradise! More to be envied than the wise And happier than the sound of flutes, Aren't you, Mister Muddy Boots? LET US FORGET Written when it was proposed that the lower ratings of the Navy should refrain from wearing decorations. God of our fathers, known of old, God of all ships and all the seas Under whose grace we still unfold The Flag of Glory to the breezeâ Lord Nelson's God, be with us yet, Let us forgetâlet us forget! We were poor sailormen, oh Lord, Who went down to Thy vasty deeps To keep the faith and pass the word Against the foulest thing that creeps: Lord God of goodness hear us yet, Let us forgetâlet us forget! Lo, any little child can tell, How in the ânightâ we chanced our necks Mid mines for blowing us to hell, And steel that raked the shuddering decksâ Judge of the faithful, hearken yet, Let us forgetâlet us forget! We sought no honours and no balm, On O.B.E.s we were not hot, A bit of something for the arm Was all we asked and all we got, Lord of the Honest Sleeve, oh yet Let us forgetâlet us forget! For now the Captains and the Kings Have served us to the last old tide, They hint that âsilver gongsâ and things, Merely conduce to beastly pride! Lord God of Decency don't fret, We must forgetâwe must forget! The âLionâ has been sold for junk, âBoy Cornwell'sâ tablet goes for scrap, I wonder are we mad or drunk? Oh, Mister Admiralty chap The King's âSure Shieldâ were we, and yet, Let us forgetâlet us forget! âWE WERE TOGETHERâ In Flanders' fields and London town, In London town and Flanders' fields, A graciousness went up and down. On English thorpe and folded grange And all the misty fields of France There fell a sweetness passing strange. And on the Shrine the Lily glows, In loveliness for loveliness, Beside the Poppy and the Rose. The call is blown, the âfarewellâ said, The silence of the Host descends: We have been present with our dead. NEWSPAPER ENQUIRY The dust complains, The worm must cry âCan we forgive The Deity?â And yet the Grace By which we live, Doth not forget Who can't forgive. SUNSET Sickle moon and smouldering star, Beauty burning in the west; Where is he that I loved best? Beauty burning in the West, Lo, an iron ache called War Gathers him to her stark breast. Sickle moon and smouldering starâ All the soul hath she possess'd Of the love that I loved best. Like a king he takes his rest, Past all loves and dreams that areâ Sickle moon and smouldering star Beauty burning in the West. PEACE They hid the bare bones of the land With banners bright and streamers gay, They took her by the lily hand, And set her in the public way. They deck'd her like a royal bride, With chaplets and with many crowns, They praised her on the country side, And pledged her in the singing towns. Yet some whose look was drawn and white, Whimper'd from out their private pain, âWe heard her crying in the night For them that may not come again!â Oh, foolish souls, if tears she shed, So saddened in her glistering state; She thought not of the happy dead, But of the traitor in the gate. âCARLTONâ âSeveral trains of wounded from the Battle of Loos arrived in London last night. . . . An officer with his arm bandaged, and limping on an umbrella, was met by a lady in evening dress. She arrived in a private motor, and the one word, âCarltonâ was all that passed between him and the chauffeur.ââDaily News. Returning from the Battle of Loos, According to the Daily Noos, With Flanders on my socks and shoes, I spake the one word âCarlton!â We came up by the boat express, My wife was there in evening dress; She'd brought the carâoh, yes; oh, yes! I said the one word, âCarlton!â I did not say, âHello, my dear, How are the chicks?â Not meâno fear: I took the chauffeur by the ear, And rapped out one word, âCarlton!â I did not say, âRejoice, rejoice, Here's Perkins on the old Rolls-Royceââ Without a tremor in my voice I said the one word, âCarlton!â Although my arm was in a sling (They got me by the liver-wing) And my foot ached like anything, I said the one word, âCarlton!â Though I was crumpled by the blast And had been worried and harass'd Upon my honour, all that passed Was just the one word, âCarlton!â Oh, gentlemen, 'twixt you and me, After the trenchesâand the seaâ This is the crown of victory To speak the one word, âCarlton!â By the âold girlâ to take your stand, With the old brolly in your hand, And say in tones that beat the band The haughty one word, âCarlton!â THE MAYFLOWER [1620-1920] Serene, august, through time she watches Her deeps alight with dawns and stars, The sea in every breath she catches, And all her front a blaze of scars. Crowned with the passion and desire That builds and reigns and builds again, She makes her women out of fire And on the waters casts her men. An hundred strong, but quick with power Unto the âWestern wildsâ they came, And landing from the worn âMayflowerâ Called them New England in her name. And when the East ran red with slaughters And Europe shook to felon guns, The Pilgrim Mothers' pilgrim daughters Sent us the Pilgrim Fathers' sons. Shall it be said we ever truckled To them that babble of âold scoresâ? Upon her bosom ye were suckled, And the blood in her heart is yours. THE CORONATION OF HIS MAJESTY GEORGE V I hear the English bugles Shout on the happy breeze, To take a thousand peoples A thousand messages, While the great dawns are waking Across the English seas. O bugles of old England Which through the world do goâ You are the bravest bugles That man will ever blow. You have the fairest music That men will ever know. We crown a King in London Of all the sea-kings bred: The fearful words are spoken, The precious balm is shed; The burden and the glory Are laid upon his head. And he is crowned in Delhi, And where the Orange flows, And in the Southern Islands, And mid the Northern snows, With one who sits beside him White as the Yorkshire rose. O bugles say your proudest With the sweet morning soundâ Unto the English peoples An English King is crowned; And may the strength which sleeps not For ever, gird him round. THE KING'S FIRST GRANDSON At Chesterfield House, at Chesterfield House, The Queen stayed for luncheon and sent for her Spouse, Andbeforethey came outâbetween you and meâ We knew very well what the business might be. At Chesterfield House, at Chesterfield House, The doctor crept in as still as a mouse, And when he came out we learnt to our joy That he'd left with the Princess a fine little boy. A fine little boy, a real Yorkshire lad, The pride of his mother and heir to his dad; He's got a white cot and a coral and bells, And the public will know him as Gerald Lascelles. Let the âFlea and the Fly and the Flitchâ now rejoice, The youth weighs eight pounds and possesses a voiceâ Fill me feyther's old mug with a drop of XX, And here's to the grandson of George the Fifth, Rex! THE HEATHER AND THE ROSE The Duke of York proposed three times.â Morning Paper. He asked the lady in the dance, She wouldna' wed for a' that; He whispered to her at the stance, She shook her head for a' that: For a' that and a' that, The King's braw son and a' that, Earl's dochters are not lightly wonâ Strathmore, Kinghorne and a' that. For a' that and a' that, He sware unto his lucky star: âI'll hae her yet, whate'er befaâ,â And rode a ride like Lochinvar: Hech, sirs, the third time paid for a', And she said: âYesâ and a' that For a' that and a' that, Ye ken the rest and a' that, âThe rank is but the guinea stamp,â And true love's love for a' that. Oh, fetch me up a pint of wine And reach me down my silver tassie, The Heather with the Rose entwine: ââHere's tae us!â and âTo me and mine!â And hansel for this Lad and Lassie!â SARAH BERNHARDT Oh triumphing Death, count up thy victories; Lo thou hast vanquished many souls of flame, And levelled to a ruin and a name Queens that were fair and kings of great emprise, And sealed with dust full many a lover's eyes, And humbled many furious ones who came Unto thy call as tamely as the tame And, meekly, with the innocent and the wise. Now lies she low that had the front of heaven And spake like singing stars. Thy marble kiss Annuls the lips and stills the heart of her And takes the wild white spirit in a snare: So unto thee at last is empiry given; Conqueror indeed art thou that conquerest this! AVE ATQUE VALE Mr Lloyd George has resigned. A great sigh of relief will go up from England as a wholeâ and will be re-echoed throughout Europe. âMorning comment. O comfortable sight! The danger past, The body salved of the unthinkable fate, The foeman carrion by the battered gate, The terrors scattered, the dull anguish cast And Glory floating sweetly at the mast: This who was prop and pillar of your State Passes as one that hath outlived his dateâ And easy comes the English breath at last! Time will be served and benefits forgot; And yet mayhap in yonder land of vines Where sleepers sleep whose memory fadeth not, Another sigh will stir the kingly lines And Valiance whisper from his clayey cot: âDid ye hear that, Billâour old pal resigns?â EDITH CAVELL May 15th, 1918 Behold, to-day, our daughter cometh home, Borne like a dead Queen in a warrior ship, With her hands folded on her English heart Which they might stillâbut could not teach to shake. Holy and humble, faithful, piteous, Unto thy bosom so returneth she; And thou art richer, England, for her dust, Who yet was meek though proud among the proud. ADMIRAL LORD FISHER âSleep soundly in your beds,â and sound we slept, âHit hard, hit everywhere,â and we hit hard; While his steel citadels around us kept Vigil and ward. Behold he sleeps the sleep that men must sleep, Hard hit as mortal men must be hard hit; And of his passing deep shall speak to deep And ponder it. Forget him not; for he was soul and breath And fist for England; and he faltered not, But âyou-be-damnedâ 'em allâeven Admiral Death Who âsacks the lot!â FOR WARREN GAMALIEL HARDING President Harding died on St. Gamaliel's Eve. Gamaliel; Of whom 'twas said, âThe glory dies Since he is dead.â Gamaliel: So did they call Thee, after him Who tutored Paul. Behold the startled Peoples grieve Thy passingâ On Gamaliel's eve . . . Beloved Of the great and free, Oh, âman Without an enemyâ: I see thy kneeling Country spread Lilies to grace Thine honour'd bed; And on thy casket For a pall, âOld Glory,â Fairer than them all. . . . And in my secret Heart I view A fold of our âOld Glory,â too. âFORGIVE THEMâ As Michael Collins lay dying by the roadside his last words were âForgive them.â From the roadside as from the Rood Unto a bow'd and desperate land, Unto the stricken multitude A-shudder at the assassin's handâ âForgive them!â For the dumb hate, and the wild fear, And malice raging in the night, And the black curse too deep to hear, And deeds too loathly for the lightâ Forgive them! For widows' tears and orphans' plaints, And good men dead beneath the sodâ And scoundreldom that quotes the Saints, And murder in the name of Godâ Forgive them! SIR HENRY WILSON Sword at your side And ribands on your breast, You fell And there was woe in Heaven, And shame confest In hell. You share with kings And captains gathered hence The crown; While Murder shrieks at large, And Innocence Bows down. THE HOME-COMING November 11th, 1920. With mournful pomp and honouring gun, Now cometh England's unknown son, Who on himself her wounds did take And lay down humbly for her sake. The England of a thousand years, Greatness and glory without peers, And kings and conquerors proud and dim Stretch their receiving arms to him. âUnknownâ yet knownâand trebly blest; For as he moves to his high rest The woman soul that made us stirs, And every mother thinks him hers. NORWICH AND AMERONGEN The ex-Kaiser makes a point of never being late for dinner, and says grace himself. âNewspaper CorrÃ«spondÃ«nt. To-night thy victim taketh up her rest In the safe keeping of her Country's breast Whilst thou, O Murderer and Son of Hell, Respondest briskly to the dinner bell, And having on thy meat a grace invoked, Dinestâunchoked! VIMY RIDGE April, 1917 On Vimy Ridge the war-light glows, New triumph for victorious browsâ So shines our Lady of the Snows, On Vimy Ridge! On Vimy Ridge the German thief Beholds our glory and his griefâ The Lads who wear the Maple-Leaf, On Vimy Ridge! On Vimy Ridge the price they pay; And, spilling riches to the clay, Mark yet another Canada, On Vimy Ridge! THE LITTLE NATION In August nineteen-thirty-seven I chanced across old John Goo-goo: He had the look of one who knew The way to heaven. He'd changed his name from âBull,â he told me, To satisfy âthe reconciled.â âWhen I was Bull, you know,â he smiled, âNothing could hold me!â âWhereas . . but s-sh, it is verboten!â All one may do is work and pray!â And, oh, his cheek was ashen greyâ Grey as Falloten! In well-patched seat and battered bowler He travestied the ancient blood; On either side of him there stood A Man-Controller! Both these I squared(though they were firm'uns), They slunk off to the Duck and Gun; âNow, John,â quoth I,,, who won, who won? We or the Germans!â Quoth he, âAlas, with lethal engines And furious stroke, we smashed their cup, But Lloyd George said âNo tearing up, Yea and no Vengeance!â âThey biffed the Old Ship in the funnel; They slew our sons as wolves slay goats; They sucked the blood out of our throats, Right through the tunnel! âYet, at the finishâwell, we're bidden To think no thoughts of get-your-own-back. We must be thankful Jerry's thrown back Upon his own effluvious midden! âAnd surely 'tis our Christian duty Fust to forgive and pay the piper, As we grow older we grow riper, So here's to Deutschland, home, and beauty! âFor while the righteous sing penillions, And Germans splutter in the chorus, With nought but âstrenuous daysâ before us, We're paying off the blinkin' millions. âOf course it seems a very meek end, To toil and moil sans wage or drinking, But still we keep a Fund called Sinking, And pay in four-pence every week-end. âAnd we have other compensations, Oh, yes we haveâfor once a year We are allowed one pint of beer, And screws of shag as well as rations. âAnd look what I've received from Neath!â [He had a permit in his hand To listen to the annual band That plays sweet hymns on Hampstead Heath.] âOh friend,â I cried, âthe situation Looks bright. Yet nobly have we stoodâ To do the little nations good We are become a little nation!â PEACE HATH HER VICTORIES âA trade war will prolong and embitter afresh hatreds which should be allowed to die.â âLord Bryce at Birmingham. The shades of night were falling fast As through the gloom of London passed A youth who'd borrowed from Lord Bryce A banner with this strange deviceâ âNo Trade War, Please!â His brow was glad: his eye beneath Flashed like a tin-sword from its sheath; And like a four-three trumpet rung The accents of his foolish tongueâ âNo Trade War, Please!â In happy homes he saw the light Of German stoves gleam warm and bright, And to the Sixpenny Bazaar He drove his German motor carâ âNo Trade War, Please!â âO stay!â the maiden said, âand rest Thy addled head upon this breast!â âI only rest my head,â quoth he, âOn blouses made in Germanyâ No Trade War, Please!â âBeware the Prussian's âEnglish Branch,â Beware the dumper's avalanche!â This was the patriot's last good night. The youth replied, âYou're wrongâI'm right!â âNo Trade War, Please!â At break of day as factoryward He plodded to find all gates barred And nothing doing anywhere, A voice cried through the startled air, âNo Trade War, Please!â And later, on the Underground, With empty pockets he was found, Still grasping in his hand of ice The banner of the gay Lord Bryceâ âNo Trade War, Please!â There on the platform cold and grey, Bankrupt but beautiful he lay; They wrapped him in a nice print shroud From Dusseldorf, and sobbed aloud âNo Trade War, Please!â And then they wired to Berlin, âThis is too muchâyou've done him in!ââ A voice fell like a falling star âPeace hath her victoriesâjust like war!â âNo Trade War, Please!â TAILS UP! I What do the English say, my lad? Tails up!âtails up! With hell let loose on a world gone mad, Tails up!âtails up! By the oaths their fathers swore, By the lilies of Agincourt, By Drake and Nelson and fifty more, Tails up!âtails up! II For thrust on thrust and wave on wave, Tails up!âtails up! We are the hammer and the grave, Tails up!âtails up! We, who have seen the soul of things, And bear upon our battling wings The glory and the blaze of kingsâ Tails up!âtails up! III Oh, youth that is age, and love that is strifeâ Tails up!âtails up! Though life be death, and death be life, Tails up!âtails up! Though there be neither end nor ease, And no more joy in breath or breeze, And the Lord forget His promisesâ Tails up!âtails up! NO CHRISTMAS âThe Kaiser has given orders prohibiting any Christmas celebrations in Germany.â âDaily Paper. âOh my!âno Christmas?â Little Fritz Thinks Mutterchen Has lost her wits! By the Kaiser's Orders, child,â No Peace on Earth No mercy mild, No waits, no bells, No fiddling, No glory for The new-born King; No plums, no flour, We mustn't make Der Kuchenâ Otherwise, the cake; No roasting, boiling, Baking, grilling While the All-Highest Does his Killing! No Holy Night For you or me, No stocking full, No sparkling tree; No mirthful parties, No burnt paws, No Christmas And no Santa Claus! Trot off to bed, The hour grows late, And mind you say Your Hymn of Hate! No Christmas! Babe Of Bethlehem! Thou who didst love And âsuffer them!â Thou who forgave us From Thy Tree! This is the final Blasphemy The murderer Of a million sons, Proceeds to rob Thy little ones! . . . No Christmas this year! Thereâdon't cry, And take your knuckle From your eye; Never despair To hope is wiserâ Perhaps, next year There'll be no Kaiser! BLIGHTY Of all the words, this is the wordâ Blighty! By soldier men the most preferredâ Blighty! It lifts them clean beyond the foam And makes them see the lights of home (O, sweeter than the honeycomb), Blighty! To India, I'm told, we owe Blighty! I'd like to bet it's English, though, Blighty! It bucks you on the hardest days, It keeps your feet in virtue's ways (The Colonel breathes it when he prays), Blighty! You think it when you cross the top, Blighty! It nerves you for the butcher's shop, Blighty! O Lord to get 'em hand-to-hand And on the squeal in No-Man's-Land, Learing your home address is âStrand, Blighty!â The chap they pip fair sings for joy, âBlighty!â And surgeon grins, âYou're lucky, boy. Blighty!â The chap that gets the proper pips, Don't sing so loud, but out it slips, The last word on his faithful lips, Blighty! The dream, the vision, the desire, Blighty! (Now there 's a line you can admire, Blighty! And you'd admire it twice as much If you'd received the front-line touch With living in a rabbit hutch), Blighty! If I remain above the grassâ Blighty! I reckon to earn a six days' passâ Blighty! Behold the end of all my woesâ The nipper in his Sunday clothes, The missus blooming like a rose, Blighty! Them that's gone West will also reach Blighty! Leastways, that's what the padres teach Blightyâ And when they're through the jasper door, And safe upon the shining floor, They'll whisper, marvelling, âWhy, sureâ It's Blighty!â FROM A POINT OF VANTAGE Bowers of bunting, bands and t' crowd, Shoutingâglad and very proud. We've done wi' murder and blood and dinâ I reckon I know'd which side would win! Ay! that's Nelsonâwell content, Wi' flags all up his monument, Only one arm an' his eye in a patchâ Same as he was last Cup Tie Match! See them âpylonsâ shine in the sun, Names of battles on every one; And there's a angelâshe that brings Peace and healing on her wings. Now they're coming! Yon's Foch! Hooray!!! An' Haig! an' Beatty, gay as gay! An' glittering âAlliesâ row on rowâ I reckon t'owd Kaiser should see us now! An' here's the lads our Joe was with . . . Lord love 'em! . . they seem like kin and kith: That's right, motherâlean on meâ I reckon we know where our lad be! THE LAST AIR RAID The wine was good, the dinner not amiss And through the window one beheld the moon, Flattering the river like a silver tuneâ Frigid and fair, and wise in her own bliss As when she took Endymion with a kiss: âWaiter! Twice now I've asked you for a spoon, And bring theâcrikey! that was a maroon!â âHimmel!âund vistles!â gasps the cringing âSviss.â So to one's flat (beneath five concrete floors), Composure, resignation, fortitude, And thoughts removed from earthliness and selfâ âCough, cough,â âbark, bark,â âcrump, crumpââand then a thud: The glasses rattle, something shakes the doors, And Nelson dithers on the mantelshelf. VISIONS I saw the rivers run a living red, I saw the gardens torn and trampled down, Rape in the field and murder in the town, And little children counting up the dead. I heard the Felon cry:âIll be my good, And Hell my province till the world shall kneel And bare its neck for my omnipotent heel!â I turned to look and saw him chopping wood! On London streets I saw the banners shine And mile on mile of glory walk between Glad miles of prideâa people who had been Fed with dread dews, tasting the perfumed wine. And last night when the moon hung very low And the flags drooped each on its sleepy mast I saw a thousand thousand wraiths that passed Through the dim aisles with solemn steps and slow. In war-stained garments, radiant and fair, Majestical to look upon, with eyes That had known death and searched out paradise They pressed as if on some high business bent: Yea, every Mother's son of them was there, Bands playing and colours flying ghostlywise, And all their music seemed to faint and fail To âTipperaryâ and the âLong, Long Trail!â TROTSKY AND THE BELLS OF DOORN Out of her ancient snows, through travail and tears and blood, Big with the spirit she rose and fashioned her empery; Fought and wrought till she stood diademedâgrasping in fee Fat land and forest and flood from arctic to summer sea. Jewelled the gold of her cup; golden the wine she poured Forth for her princes to sup; golden the grain she storedâ Merchant unto the world, withal that the world might be fed; Keeping the wheatless in sheavesâand keeping the fearless in dread: Ah, mighty and awesome and proud, inviolable, august Goest thou now in thy shroud; stretchest thou now in the dust? THE LAST SONNET All these bright shapes and visions of delight, This turret of gold, this chair of amethyst Put thou away; the cheek that Judas kiss'd, The body of death worn in the unending fight, One to the worm, the other to the kite. Put thou away the sharp steel and the fist, And let the foolish wanton as they list. Another thief hath entered in the night. So are we served, triumphant and elate. What of the darkened Kingdom then remains That the grooms mark our passing with such state? This is the perfume of our ice-cold veins: We made considerable mirth of fate, And on the stair of Hell we break our chains.
